document.docAuthor: Santos, Aluska Tavares Dos & Ribeiro-Costa, Cibele Stramare
document.masterDocTitle: Rearrangements in some species groups of Amblycerus Thunberg, 1815 (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Bruchinae) including keys, description of a new species, new host plant and distributional records

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rearrangements in some species groups of Amblycerus Thunberg, 1815 (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Bruchinae) including keys, description of a new species, new host plant and distributional records

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Spermophagus dispar
Sharp, 1885: 494
(desc., distr.). For review of literature, see
Ribeiro-Costa et al . (2018)
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Types
. The species was recognized through its original description and works by Ribeiro-Costa ( Ribeiro-Costa 1995 ; Kingsolver & Ribeiro-Costa 1997 ) that illustrated the male genitalia and examined the type material of
A. dispar
as well as of its synonyms, with the exception of
Spermophagus thomasi
. For the synonymical list of
A. dispar
, see
Ribeiro-Costa et al . (2018)
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription . Measurements . BL: 7.9 mm; BW: 4.0 mm.

Integument color ( Fig. 10 )
. Red to dark red.

Vestiture ( Figs 10 , 36 , 49 , 79 )
. Body covered with light yellow setae. Pronotum with six vaguely dense patches and a median basal line of setae. Elytra with setae uniformly distributed; pygidium with median stripe of setae.

Head ( Fig. 23 )
. Eyes approximate anteriorly, ocular index: 9.5, ocular sinus 1.3 and postocular lobe about 0.4 the eye length. Frons covered with fine and moderately dense coarse punctures, with frontal carina. Antennae reaching anterior margin of hindcoxae, serrate on antennomeres 4–10; antennomere 7 about 1.5 longer than wide, last antennomere subelliptic. Frontoclypeal suture distinct. Clypeus covered with moderately coarse punctures, except near apex, where it is smooth. Labrum with few fine coarse punctures on basal margin.
Prothorax ( Figs 36 , 49 )
. Pronotum trapezoidal with lateral margins slightly curved, covered entirely by coarse and dense punctures ( Fig. 49 ); lateral carina almost reaching posterior margin of pronotum; cervical boss with three setae; cervical sulcus conspicuous behind eyes. Prosternal process longer than anterior coxae, gently arched between coxae and slightly constricted between coxae.
Meso- and metathorax ( Figs 2 , 10 , 36 , 63, 64)
. Scutellum about 1.7 longer than wide, tridentate, median tooth longer than the lateral ones ( Figs 2 , 63, 64). Elytra with striae strongly impressed, at basal third striae 1–6 with punctures more isolated, 6–7 striae fused apically ( Fig. 10 ). Metepisternum without coarse punctures; metepisternal sulcus with transverse axis gently oblique or straight; the longitudinal axis about half the lenght of metepisternum. Metaventrite not prominent in lateral view, without punctures and median sulcus longer than a half the lenght of metaventrite ( Fig. 36 ). Metacoxae with coarse punctures. Hindtibia with lateral spur about 2.8 times the length of median spur. First tarsomere about 1.6 the length of the lateral spur and 4.5 times the length of median spur.
Abdomen ( Figs 36 , 79 )
. Ventrites with moderately coarse punctures ( Fig. 36 ); last ventrite almost as long as ventrite IV. Pygidium with apical margin rounded and with coarse and dense punctures ( Fig. 79 ).

Male genitalia ( Figs 92 , 98 )
. Median lobe of male genitalia about 4.5 times as long as its greatest width at apical region ( Fig. 92 ); ventral valve with lateral margins concave and acuminate apex; dorsal valve subtriangular, with lateral margins almost straight. Internal sac in the apical region without sclerites, some small spines dispersed ( Fig. 92 ). Median region with J-shaped unpaired sclerite, two vertical lines of denticles, two groups of denticles, and two laminar hat-shaped sclerites with denticles at apex. Basal region with several small denticles close to ejaculatory duct. Tegmen with deep, rounded emargination between the enlarged lateral lobes ( Fig. 98 ). Female . Similar to male except ventrite V not emarginate.

Distribution ( Fig. 117 )
. Curaçao , Honduras , Panama , Venezuela , French Guiana , Brazil (Pará, Mato Grosso , Ceará , Paraíba , Pernambuco , Bahia , Rio de Janeiro ), Peru , Paraguay ( new country record ), Argentina and Chile .

Life History . According to
Johnson et al . (2001)
, the larvae of
A. dispar
feed only on one seed during their entire development, while in other species of the genus it is common to find one larva feeding on several seeds during their development.

Host Plants ( Tab. I )
.
Fabaceae
:
Geoffroea decorticans (Gillies ex Hook. & Arn.) Burkart.
Rhamnaceae
:
Sarcomphalus mistol (Griseb.) Havenschild
( new record )
Ziziphus joazeiro Mart.
;
Ziziphus
sp.
Anacardiaceae
:
Spondias tuberose Arruda.
